Article Title: Netflix suffers outage during ‘Stranger Things’ finale premiere
Article Text:
Netflix outage : User reactions





Stranger Things Scandal: Millie Bobby Brown Files Harassment Complaint Against Co-Star David Harbour





Netflix faced a widespread outage in some regions on Wednesday (November 26). Netflix received a wave of complaints from its users as the platform experienced a sudden outage during the premiere of the finale of much-awaited show Stranger Things. Due to the outage, thousands of Netflix subscribers were not able to stream the show which lead to a flood of posts across social media.According to a report by outrage tracking website DownDetector, a sharp spike in the outage alerts started shortly after the episode dropped. Users reported that they were facing issues with logging in and complete service failure. As per DownDetector, 55% users complained of video streaming issues, 36% faced server connection issues and 9% were not able to login.Many users also posted about the outage on social media platform X (formerly known as Twitter). Hashtags such as #NetflixDown and #StrangerThings quickly started trending after the outage. “I waited damn near 3 years for stranger things season 5 and you mean to tell me Netflix is DOWN ??!,” wrote a user on X.“Well the Netflix servers are down....This was expected with the FINAL season of Stranger Things,” said another user.Many users also shared the screenshots of error messages, while others joked that the “Upside Down” had taken over Netflix itself.The timing of the outage was particularly damaging given the cultural weight of the Stranger Things finale, which marks the conclusion of one of Netflix’s most successful franchises. The series has been a cornerstone of the streaming giant’s original programming since its debut in 2016, and the finale was expected to draw record-breaking viewership.
Article Summary: Netflix faced a widespread outage in some regions on Wednesday (November 26) Users reported that they were facing issues with logging in and complete service failure. The timing of the outage was particularly damaging given the cultural weight of the Stranger Things finale, which marks the conclusion of one of Netflix’s most successful franchises.

Article Title: Microsoft AI CEO Mustafa Suleyman says ‘Superintelligence can be the best invention ever’ but there’s a condition
Article Text:
ASI should be an 'Anti-Goal': Suleyman





Microsoft AI CEO Mustafa Suleyman has again issued a warning about the future of artificial intelligence (AI), saying that superintelligence can be humanity's greatest breakthrough, but only if it prioritises human interests above all else. “Superintelligence could be the best invention ever – but only if it puts the interests of humans above everything else,” Suleyman wrote on X, framing the challenge facing AI researchers as they race toward increasingly powerful systems.Suleyman’s latest warning comes days after he spoke on an episode of the Silicon Valley Girl Podcast, urging researchers to treat artificial superintelligence (ASI), which is nothing but an AI with reasoning capabilities far exceeding human capacity, as an “anti-goal” rather than a development target.“It doesn't feel like a positive vision of the future. It would be very hard to contain something like that or align it to our values,” Suleyman said of ASI, citing the immense risks of controlling such technology.Suleyman also revealed his team is pursuing what he calls “humanist superintelligence” – advanced AI designed explicitly to support and prioritise human interests rather than operate as an independent superintelligent entity.Microsoft’s AI CEO also pushed back against speculation about AI consciousness. He warned researchers saying that simulation and genuine consciousness or granting AI systems moral status must be avoided.“These things don't suffer. They don't feel pain. They're just simulating high-quality conversation,” he explained. Earlier this month, Suleyman went further, advising developers to abandon research exploring AI consciousness altogether. He argued that consciousness remains an exclusively biological trait and that pursuing it in artificial systems is fundamentally misguided.“I don't think that is work that people should be doing. If you ask the wrong question, you end up with the wrong answer. I think it's totally the wrong question,” Suleyman stated.
Article Summary: Mustafa Suleyman says superintelligence can be humanity's greatest breakthrough, but only if it prioritises human interests above all else. He urges researchers to treat artificial superintelligence (ASI) as an ‘anti-goal’ rather than a development target. Earlier this month, he advised developers to abandon research exploring AI consciousness.

Google CEO Sundar Pichai recently shared a post on X, formerly Twitter, announcing a new breakthrough in quantum algorithms. “Our Willow chip has achieved the first-ever verifiable quantum advantage,” Pichai wrote in the post, adding it is “13,000x faster than the best classical algorithm on one of the world's fastest supercomputers”. Pichai’s post caught the attention of Tesla CEO Elon Musk . The tech billionaire replied to Pichai’s post saying “Congrats. Looks like quantum computing is becoming relevant.”Announcing the major breakthrough, Google CEO Sundar Pichai wrote:The achievement marks a historic breakthrough in quantum computing. For the first time ever, a quantum computer has performed a complex, verifiable calculation faster than any supercomputer could — about 13,000 times faster. Article Title: Two 15-year-old kids challenge Australia’s social media ban for teens: ‘robs young Australians of…’
Article Text:
‘Like Orwell's 1984, and its scares me’

What the Australian government has to say





Two Australian teenagers have launched a constitutional challenge against the social media ban for under-16s, filing their case in the High Court of Australia, which is the nation's highest court, just two weeks before the law takes effect. Noah Jones and Macy Neyland, both 15, are serving as plaintiffs in proceedings initiated by the Digital Freedom Project at the court. According to a report by news agency Reuters, the campaign group filed the challenge on Wednesday (November 26), seeking to block legislation.The law will force social media platforms, including YouTube , TikTok, Snapchat, and Meta-owned Facebook as well as Instagram to deactivate more than one million accounts held by Australian teenagers when the ban begins December 10.The Digital Freedom Project argues the ban violates young Australians' freedom of political communication—an implied constitutional right in a country without express free speech protections. “The legislation is grossly excessive,” the group was quoted as saying. It also claimed that it “robs” minors of fundamental rights.Neyland said that the law would silence youth voices on critical issues.“Young people like me are the voters of tomorrow... we shouldn't be silenced.It's like Orwell's book 1984, and that scares me,” she said.Communications Minister Anika Wells dismissed the legal challenge shortly after it was announced, telling Parliament that the government will not back down.“Despite the fact that we are receiving threats and legal challenges by people with ulterior motives, the Albanese Labor government remains steadfastly on the side of parents, and not of platforms,” Wells said.The teenagers aren't the only ones preparing legal action. Australian media reports indicate YouTube has also threatened a High Court challenge, arguing the ban unconstitutionally burdens political communication.The ban was passed into law in November 2024, and is said to represent one of the world’s most comprehensive attempts to regulate minors' social media access. Tech companies face steep penalties for non-compliance: up to A$49.5 million ($32.22 million) in fines.
Article Summary: Two Australian teenagers have launched a constitutional challenge against the social media ban for under-16s. Noah Jones and Macy Neyland, both 15, are serving as plaintiffs in proceedings initiated by the Digital Freedom Project. The law will force social media platforms, including YouTube, TikTok, Snapchat, and Meta-owned Facebook as well as Instagram to deactivate more than one million accounts held by Australian teenagers.

This rumoured agreement is taking place while Taiwan seeks to reduce the current 20% tariff applied to its exports to the US. Article Text:
Overspending and the AI Bubble





What Is Artificial Intelligence? Explained Simply With Real-Life Examples

Disruption will come from the unexpected





Take lessons from the dot-com era









Billionaire investor and Shark Tank judge Mark Cuban has now issued a warning to leading artificial intelligence companies including Perplexity, OpenAI, Anthropic, Google, Microsoft and Meta. Cuban has argued that all these companies are overspending in the race to build the world’s most powerful AI model. As reported by Business Insider, speaking in the Pioneers of AI podcast, Cuban compared today’s AI arms race to the search engine boom of 1990s. The search engine boom ultimately ended with Google dominating the market and leaving all the rivals behind.“You’ve got five, six, whatever it is, companies that are trying to create the ultimate foundational model that we all depend on,” Cuban said. “It’s almost like in the ’90s when all the search engines were competing pre-Google… Now, we know with search engines it’s Google, and then there’s Bing, as, like, 1 or 2% and DuckDuckGo has got a half a percent. So it’s effectively a winner-take-all.”Like many other world leaders and analysts Cuban has also cautioned that the massive investments done on AI could ultimately lead to the creation of a bubble. “They may be overspending,” he said.“And if they overspend or get too caught up, the bubble is in the competition between all those models because that could pop just like that with any new technology.”Along with this, he also raised concerns about the infrastructure costs behind AI, majorly the massive and expensive data centers which are being built to power large models. “I just can’t imagine over a 10-year period that we aren’t going to improve the technology enough that if you overspend on today’s technology, it just doesn’t feel right to me,” Cuban added.Cuban also emphasised that the disruption AI will not come from incremental improvements but from something “incredible” that no one sees coming. “Somebody’s going to come up with some incredible shit, right? If I knew what it was, I’d do it,” he said, suggesting that the current race may be blindsided by a breakthrough outside the existing competition.Cuban said he recognizes the same mix of hype, excitement, and overspending now playing out in AI. “They anticipate for at least another decade spending every penny they have,” he said of the major model developers. “I mean, if that’s not ripe for disruption to come up with better ways, I don’t know what is.”

It’s an amazing thing. But one of the things that has gone wrong is that when I use the current devices or most apps, I feel like I am walking through Times Square in New York, constantly dealing with all the little indignities along the way. Flashing lights in my face, tension going on here, people bumping into me like noise is going off.

You can then go for a vibe that is not like walking through Times Square, getting bumped into, and having all this stuff compete for your attention. But like sitting in the most beautiful cabin by a lake and in the mountains, and enjoying the peace and calm. I think this actually just isn’t possible in the pre-AI world of technology. Article Title: 80,000 code snippets From banks, governments, and technology company leaked: Cloud passwords, payment keys, personal data exposed
Article Text:
AI generated image for representation

What got leaked and why it matters

Hackers already hunting for these secrets





Thousands of passwords, security keys, and confidential information from banks, government agencies, and tech companies have been sitting exposed online through two popular code formatting websites, JSONFormatter and CodeBeautify. Security researchers discovered over 80,000 saved code snippets—totaling more than 5GB of data spanning up to five years—freely accessible to anyone through an unprotected feature called "Recent Links" on both platforms.The exposed material includes working login credentials for cloud services and databases, private encryption keys, payment gateway access codes, and massive amounts of personal customer data from organizations in critical sectors like banking, healthcare, government infrastructure, aerospace, and cybersecurity, according to a report by Bleeping Computer. Among the discoveries: active Amazon Web Services credentials from a major international stock exchange, banking passwords leaked by a cybersecurity service provider, and internal system configurations from government entities.The problem stems from how these tools handle saved code. When users click "save" to share their formatted code, the platforms create a public link and add it to an unprotected "Recent Links" page.Because these pages follow predictable web addresses, anyone can easily scrape them using simple automated tools.The exposed data includes highly sensitive material that cybercriminals could exploit immediately. Researchers from WatchTowr found login credentials for databases and cloud services, private encryption keys, payment gateway access codes, and large amounts of personal customer information.In specific cases, they discovered working Amazon Web Services credentials from a major international stock exchange, banking credentials leaked by a security service provider, and configuration details from a cybersecurity firm that included passwords, internal network information, and system blueprints.One government entity inadvertently exposed 1,000 lines of code containing details about internal systems, security settings, and network configurations—information that attackers could use to plan intrusions.To test whether criminals were actively monitoring these sites, researchers planted fake but realistic-looking security credentials. The bait was accessed within 48 hours, confirming that threat actors are scanning these platforms for exploitable information, Bleeping Computer reports.While WatchTowr notified affected organisations, many haven't responded. The "Recent Links" features remain publicly accessible on both websites, continuing to expose sensitive data to potential attackers.
Article Summary: Security researchers discovered over 80,000 saved code snippets spanning up to five years. They were exposed through an unprotected feature called "Recent Links" on both platforms. The exposed material includes working login credentials for cloud services and databases, private encryption keys, and payment gateway access codes.

How AI is transforming skilling in India









India is at a defining moment in its AI journey and Microsoft is partnering with the government to embed AI learning directly into vocational institutions and communities nationwide, Microsoft India and South Asia president Puneet Chandok has said, noting that the tech giant is helping in building a future-ready workforce capable of thriving in an AI-powered economy.“India stands at a defining moment in its AI journey and what sets this moment apart is the nation’s resolve to make AI opportunity inclusive. At Microsoft, we see skilling as the cornerstone of this transformation. By combining India’s scale of talent with its strong digital foundation and by partnering with the Government of India, MSDE, and DGT, we are embedding AI learning into vocational institutions and communities nationwide. This is more than a program—it’s a movement to build a future-ready workforce,” Chandok said.Microsoft has shared an example of Satyendra Kumaris part of a growing cohort of over 350 students trained in a one-year micro-degree ‘AI Programming Assistant’, offered across 33 National Skill Training Institutes (NSTIs) in India.The company says that it partnered with the Directorate General of Training (DGT) at the Ministry of Skill Development and Entrepreneurship (MSDE) to deliver the program that is advancing India’s mission to prepare its youth for an AI-driven economy.Earlier this year, Microsoft announced its AI skilling commitment to train 10 million Indians by 2030. According to Microsoft, over 5.6 million Indians have already been trained by Microsoft since the announcement in January 2025.It also announced Microsoft Elevate, which aims to provide education, nonprofit, and workforce organisations with technology solutions, skills and insights to empower people in the AI economy. As AI reshapes the world of work, Microsoft said, its skilling approach must evolve to match the pace of innovation and opportunity it brings.Jayant Chaudhary, Minister of State for Skill Development & Entrepreneurship noted the role of private technology firms like Microsoft and how it is modernizing ITIs (Industrial Training Institutes) and NSTIs.“Collaborations with industry leaders are helping establish AI labs, enhance curriculum and pedagogy as well as create hands-on learning ecosystems aligned with industry needs,” he said.This gap in vocational skilling becomes even more critical when viewed against the backdrop of India’s booming AI market.
Article Summary: Microsoft is partnering with the government to embed AI learning directly into vocational institutions and communities nationwide. The tech giant is helping in building a future-ready workforce capable of thriving in an AI-powered economy. Earlier this year, Microsoft announced its AI skilling commitment to train 10 million Indians by 2030.

Article Title: Slack cofounder on the 'fake work' that troubles both startup CEOs and their employees
Article Text:
Slack cofounder tells how productive teams fall into the ' fake work ' trap

Leadership must define what counts as real work, says Butterfield







Stewart Butterfield, who led Slack from startup to a $27.7 billion Salesforce acquisition, warns that executives and employees alike waste time on what he calls "hyper-realistic worklike activities" — tasks that look productive but deliver little value. Speaking on Lenny's Podcast, the serial entrepreneur who also founded Flickr identified a pattern he observed while scaling companies: as organizations grow, workers increasingly engage in what appears to be legitimate work but actually accomplishes nothing meaningful. Pre-meetings to review presentation decks, endless slide revisions, and status updates that serve no strategic purpose all fall into this category.The problem begins in a company's early days, Butterfield explained. Initially, every task delivers clear value — setting up bank accounts, building user databases, establishing core systems. But as companies hire more people, the supply of obvious, high-value work diminishes while the workforce expands.Without transparent priorities from leadership, employees create busy work to demonstrate productivity.They're not being lazy or deceptive, Butterfield clarified — they simply want recognition for their efforts and will conform to whatever their team culture rewards.The most insidious aspect of fake work is its subtlety. Even board members and executives fall into the trap, Butterfield admitted on the podcast, because these activities mirror legitimate business tasks so closely.The responsibility for fixing this rests squarely with leadership, he argued. CEOs and managers must explicitly communicate priorities and say no to low-value activities upfront, rather than blaming workers later for wasted effort.Butterfield's critique of superficial productivity comes from experience. After leaving Slack in early 2023, he's had time to reflect on the organisational patterns that emerge as startups mature into major corporations. His message: looking busy isn't the same as being effective, and leaders must constantly distinguish between the two.
Article Summary: Stewart Butterfield, who led Slack from startup to a $27.7 billion Salesforce acquisition, warns that executives and employees alike waste time on what he calls "hyper-realistic worklike activities" The problem begins in a company's early days, Butterfield explained. As companies hire more people, the supply of obvious, high-value work diminishes.

Article Title: Deloitte makes 'AI mistake' again, this time in report for Canadian government; here's what went wrong
Article Text:
Deloitte makes 'AI mistake' again



Reactions and concerns about the report made by Deloitte



Deloitte to refund Australian government $290,000 after making 'AI mistake'



Erroneous errors in Deloitte report







Deloitte has once again landed in trouble for an apparent AI-related mistake. Deloitte recently prepared a major healthcare report for the Canadian government. As reported by The Independent, the report was supposed to access healthcare services in Newfoundland and Labrador, contained multiple factual errors that are believed to be generated by artificial intelligence tools. This is not the first time that Deloitte has faced such a situation. Last month, the company refunded around $290,000 to the Australian government after errors were discovered in a report it produced.As reported by The Independent, the reported submitted by Deloitte consisted of incorrect information about hospitals and healthcare facilities. Some of the institution were either misidentified or described inaccurately. The observers also noted that text of some paragraphs of the report are AI-generated. This action done by Deloitte raises concern about the company’s reliance on automated systems without sufficient human oversight. The errors in the report were significant enough to undermine confidence in the findings of the report as it was made to guide the healthcare policy decisions in the province.As per the report, the healthcare professionals and policymakers have raised alarm, stressing that the inaccurate data of the report could mislead the decision-making in critical areas such as patient care and resource allocation.Along with this, the crisis also argued that Deloitte’s repeated missteps also highlight the risks involved in over-reliance on AI in sensitive government work.This incident underscores the increasing concern on the use of generative AI in official reports and consulting work, where accuracy is of prime importance. Also, the government and corporations are increasingly adopting AI tools to cut costs and speed up the process of analysis. However, in the case of Deloitte it clearly highlight how errors can erode credibility and trust. This incident may also prompt the Canadian authorities to re-examine oversight mechanisms for contractors using AI in public-sector projects.Last month also, Deloitte made a similar ‘AI mistake’. In August this year, Australian Financial Review (AFR) reported multiple errors in the report which also included the use of generative artificial intelligence (AI). The report, commissioned by the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations (DEWR), assessed the Targeted Compliance Framework (TCF), part of the IT system that manages welfare and benefits payments.The original seven-month review, completed around June 2025 for USD $290,000 ($440,000 AUD), contained multiple mistakes. These included nonexistent academic references and a fabricated quote from a Federal Court judgment, first noted by Australian welfare academic Dr. Christopher Rudge. An updated version of the report, published on DEWR’s website, corrected more than a dozen references and footnotes, rewrote the reference list, and fixed typographical errors.Deloitte confirmed that some footnotes and references were incorrect and has agreed to repay the final installment under its contract. A DEWR spokesperson said the changes do not alter the report’s findings or recommendations.
Article Summary: Deloitte has once again landed in trouble for an apparent AI-related mistake. The company prepared a major healthcare report for the Canadian government. The report contained multiple factual errors that are believed to be generated by artificial intelligence tools. Last month, the company refunded around $290,000 to the Australian government after errors were discovered in a report it produced.

It all started in 2016 when the European Commission wanted to address the privacy concerns of users in the European Union and the European Economic Area. The foundation of General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) was laid and multiple other countries followed their lead. The regulators started to build on these rules, self-appointing as global standard-setters for digital ethics, privacy and antitrust enforcement. The message was clear: If you want to sell to millions of Europeans, you play by Europe’s rules.Soon after the launch of ChatGPT in November 2022, the European Union (EU) moved to position itself as AI’s global regulator, proposing comprehensive legislation to hold tech companies accountable for safe AI deployment. But as the EU AI Act took shape, its increasingly ‘tough’ requirements threatened to constrain the very innovation it sought to govern.Meanwhile, in November 2022, the DMA officially entered into force with an aim to ensure a higher degree of competition in European digital markets by preventing large companies from abusing their market power. In May 2023, the regulation became applicable.Then came the backlash. Tech giants responded with legal challenges and appeals. Companies like Apple and Meta have appealed the European Commission’s non-compliance decisions and associated fines. Microsoft and Google also retaliated but complied with some demands under the law.The AI law also saw its fair share of criticism. Siemens CEO Roland Busch and SAP CEO Christian Klein slammed the EU’s AI Act, saying that “the EU's regulatory approach is holding back progress.” In fact, Prince Constantijn of the Netherlands also said that the approach may become a reason for the region to fall behind the US and China on AI development.But the world’s 'digital referee' refused to back down, as generative AI began reshaping the global economy. Tech giants were grilled and fined, sending the landscape of global technology regulation in a seismic shift.In January 2025, Donald Trump returned as the US President and reports of Tech CEOs meeting with the President started to surface. The rules essentially forced companies like Google, Apple, Microsoft, Facebook-parent Meta and others to bring changes to their respective platforms. This approach is contrary to the US ‘light approach’, where tech giants are pushed to make voluntary commitments and certain executive orders that can be modified.The ‘fight’ between the regulators and tech companies largely centred around the High-Risk category, which covers AI used in critical infrastructure, education, employment, and more. For a company like Microsoft, Google, or OpenAI, having their foundation models or applications classified as “high risk” triggers a heavy compliance burden. Under the law, they are required to prove their training data isn't biased, maintain detailed technical documentation, ensure human oversight, and achieve high levels of accuracy and cybersecurity.Unable to meet the requirements, they face the threat of fines up to 7% of global annual turnover for non-compliance.According to Pritam, co-founder and COO of Vibestudio, an India-based AI lab developing secure and on-premise AI systems for coding, automation and workforce productivity, the regulation is the reason why there’s some level of competition.Brussels believed that just as the GDPR forced companies globally to adopt privacy standards, the AI Act would force US companies to build “safe” AI for the whole world.When asked whether a long-term aim of the EU’s AI rules was to push US tech companies to invest more in the region, Aniket Tapre, founder and CEO of Neural Arc, said that the EU has always attempted to balance innovation with regulatory oversight.Companies like Google, Apple and Meta challenged the feasibility of the DMA, echoing that it will negatively impact the safe and secure experience.Google said itApple said that the commission unfairly targeted the company with moves that “are bad for the privacy and security of our users, bad for products, and force us to give away our technology for free.”Meanwhile, as the AI Act moved from draft to law, the tone from Silicon Valley quickly changed. The explosion of Generative AI (GenAI) in 2023 changed the situation and AI was touted as the next big technological revolution.Big Tech started arguing that the EU rules’ strict requirements on data transparency would force them to reveal trade secrets and open them up to massive copyright lawsuits. They argued that getting government approval before releasing a model would slow down innovation, leaving Europe behind while the US and China would surge ahead.For Ankush Sabharwal, founder and CEO of CoRover.ai, it comes down to AI investment and talent.US tech leaders realised that fighting the EU in European courts was a slow battle. This can be said on the basis of the fact that the European Court of Justice (ECJ) had recently upheld massive fines against Google and forced Apple to pay €13 billion in back taxes.In the months leading up to the US election, tech CEOs began to meet with Donald Trump. Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg, who Trump had once threatened with prison, reportedly had dinner with the former President. Zuckerberg’s tone shifted noticeably; he publicly praised Trump.Apple CEO Tim Cook called Trump directly to complain about the EU’s fines. Lutnick has publicly criticised the EU’s “anti-business” environment. Lutnick said that Europe should “reconsider” its rules for big tech companies in return for lower US tariff rates on its steel and aluminium exports.According to Tapre,All in all, Trump successfully communicated that the US government will no longer act as a passive observer while its most valuable companies are regulated by foreign powers. He turned the tech regulation into a trade issue, and forced the EU to postpone its policy implementation with the full application of high-risk AI rules being pushed back. Instead of the August 2026 deadline, the new proposal makes the deadline conditional.

Article Title: Nvidia publicly responds to 'losing' $250 billion to 'Google deal,' declares: We are…
Article Text:
Google's TPUs emerge as serious challenger to Nvidia dominance

Wall Street takes notice as competitive dynamics shift





Nvidia, the $4 trillion chipmaker that has dominated the AI boom, broke from its usual playbook Tuesday by issuing a public statement defending its market position—a move triggered by reports that one of its biggest customers, Meta Platforms, is in advanced talks to spend billions on Google 's competing AI chips. This hammered Nvidia's stock, erasing roughly $250 billion in market value. Meanwhile, Alphabet shares climbed as Wall Street began viewing Google's TPU processors as a credible alternative to Nvidia's stranglehold on AI hardware.The chipmaker, which dominates over 90% of the AI accelerator market, found itself in unfamiliar territory: responding to a competitor rather than setting the agenda. The catalyst was a report from The Information revealing that Google has been aggressively pitching its tensor processing units (TPUs) to major clients, including Meta and several leading financial institutions, potentially capturing up to 10% of Nvidia's annual revenue."We're delighted by Google's success—they've made great advances in AI, and we continue to supply to Google," Nvidia wrote, before pivoting to assert its superiority. "Nvidia is a generation ahead of the industry—it's the only platform that runs every AI model and does it everywhere computing is done."The threat to Nvidia appears increasingly credible. For most of the past decade, Google's TPUs were dismissed as clever in-house tools—fast and efficient for Google's own systems, but not a true rival to Nvidia's general-purpose GPUs.That perception is rapidly changing.Google's latest Gemini 3 AI model—trained entirely on TPUs rather than Nvidia's GPUs—has earned widespread acclaim from industry heavyweights. Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff publicly declared he's switching from ChatGPT after three years, calling Gemini 3 superior. Some analysts are describing it as the "current state of the art" in AI models.According to The Information, Meta could begin renting TPUs from Google Cloud as early as next year, with purchases for its own data centers potentially starting in 2027. This matters enormously because Meta ranks among Nvidia's largest customers, planning up to $72 billion in AI infrastructure spending this year. For Google to capture even a fraction of that business would represent a seismic shift in the AI hardware market.The deal would also mark Google's expansion beyond its current strategy of using TPUs exclusively in its own data centers, positioning the company in direct competition for the hundreds of billions being spent on AI processors.Market reaction was swift and decisive. While Nvidia shares sank, Alphabet stock surged 4%, approaching a historic $4 trillion valuation. Broadcom, which manufactures Google's AI chips, jumped 11%.Google maintained a measured response: "We are experiencing accelerating demand for both our custom TPUs and Nvidia GPUs; we are committed to supporting both."
Article Summary: Google's TPUs emerge as serious challenger to Nvidia dominance of the AI market. Google has been aggressively pitching its tensor processing units (TPUs) to major clients, including Meta and several leading financial institutions. Google maintained a measured response: "We are experiencing accelerating demand for both our custom T PUs and Nvidia GPUs"

Article Title: Optus Outage: Australia's second-largest telecommunications provider Optus suffers another emergency call failure: Here’s what the company said
Article Text:
Optus outage what the company said



Optus faced a service outage in September







Australia’s second-largest operator Optus has witnessed a significant outage on Tuesday (November 25). As reported by Reuters, the outage affected the access the emergency services (Triple Zero) which sparked widespread concern over public safety. Optus has also confirmed that some of the customers were not able to connect to Triple Zero, which is Australia’s emergency hotline at the time of the outage. This service outrage affected both mobile and fixed-line services, but the company said that majority of the call were still able to connect. The Australian authorities has also urged the users to use some alternative numbers or contact local police and fire stations directly if they are not able to access the emergency hotline.Optus spokesperson Jane McNamara told ABC Radio that the company has not seen any disruption in services. “We do have photo evidence, very clear, that there has been a cut made," she said, adding: "We know copper has been removed from the pit and we have contacted Victoria Police."On the other hand, Optus also shared a messages on its website which reads, "Customers will only be able to call emergency services if they are within coverage of another mobile network or are able to call via WiFi.”Optus, owned by Singapore Telecommunications (STEL.SI) , opens new tab, said an "aerial fibre break" could be the cause of the outage, which was being investigated.In September Optus faced an emergency call outage. As reported by Reuters, the latest incident occurred on Sunday morning in Dapto, about 100 km south of Sydney, affecting around 4,500 customers. The report also revealed that the Australian government is looking for answers about the disruption.As per the Reuters report, Optus revealed that a faulty mobile tower site interrupted services which included access to emergency numbers. The telecom service providers has confirmed that the issue has been resolved and that “all callers who attempted to contact emergency services are OK.”"Singtel takes this matter seriously and will extend full co-operation to the Australian government and authorities to address the Optus issue,” the spokesperson told Reuters."Optus continues to investigate the cause ... the issue has been restored," a spokesperson said by email.
Article Summary: Australia's second-largest operator Optus has witnessed a significant outage on Tuesday (November 25) The outage affected the access the emergency services (Triple Zero) which sparked widespread concern over public safety. Optus said an "aerial fibre break" could be the cause of the outage, which was being investigated.

Article Title: Microsoft’s AI chatbot Copilot to exit WhatsApp on January 15
Article Text:
Why Microsoft is removing its AI assistant Copilot from WhatsApp

Satya Nadella Steps Back to Focus on AI: Microsoft’s Major Reorganisation Explained

What will happen next

Copilot mobile app: Available on iOS and Android

Copilot on the web: copilot.com

Copilot on Windows





Microsoft has announced that its AI assistant Copilot will not be available on popular instant messaging app WhatsApp starting January 15, 2026. The announcement marks the end of popular integration which enabled the users to chat with Copilot directly via the messaging app. “Since launching in late 2024, Copilot on WhatsApp has helped millions of people connect with their AI companion in a familiar, everyday setting. We’re incredibly proud of the impact it’s had. But starting January 15, 2026, Copilot will no longer be available on WhatsApp,” said Microsoft in an official blog post.Microsoft has revealed that this change is part of change of WhatsApp policies. “This is due to recent updates to WhatsApp’s platform policies removing all LLM chatbots from the platform effective January 15th, and as a result, Copilot will be discontinued. We’re working to ensure a smooth transition for users and enable their continued Copilot access on mobile, web, and PC,” said the company.WhatsApp users will be able to access Copilot till January 15, 2026. After this, the service will not be available on the messaging app. However, users can still continue to chat with Copilot anytime using other modes such as:It is important to note that the Copilot chat history of users from WhatsApp will not be saved when they move to other Microsoft platforms because access to the chatbot on WhatsApp was unauthenticated. Microsoft has advised the users to retain their conversations for future reference and export them using WhatsApp’s built-in tool. "If you’d like to keep a record of your conversations, we recommend exporting your chat history using WhatsApp’s built-in tools prior to January 15, 2026," said Microsoft.
Article Summary: WhatsApp users will be able to access Copilot till January 15, 2026. After this, the service will not be available on the messaging app. Microsoft has advised the users to retain their conversations for future reference and export them using WhatsApp’s built-in tool.
